item.title: Version 1.5.2 on Rails 6.0.1 causing deprecation warning
item.description:
Rails 6.0.1
Gem version 1.5.2

In config/application.rb,
`require \"action_view/component\"`

Causing:
```
DEPRECATION WARNING: Initialization autoloaded the constants ActionText::ContentHelper and ActionText::TagHelper.

Being able to do this is deprecated. Autoloading during initialization is going
to be an error condition in future versions of Rails.

Reloading does not reboot the application, and therefore code executed during
initialization does not run again. So, if you reload ActionText::ContentHelper, for example,
the expected changes won't be reflected in that stale Module object.

These autoloaded constants have been unloaded.

Please, check the \"Autoloading and Reloading Constants\" guide for solutions.
(called from
at /Users/
USER/Projects/rails-app-test/config/environment.rb:5)
```
at `development.log`

Which is highly difficult to track

Related issue https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/36546 "

item.title: Allow rendering components in the controller
item.description:
Hi @joelhawksley

I am happy to see a view model lib, that integrates smoothly with rails. While playing around with `ActionView::Component` i noticed that it is not possible to render components in the controller. I saw, that you are monkey patching `ActionView::Base#render`. So i tried to override the `render` method in my `ApplicationController` in a similar way, but without success.

At the moment users are forced to write templates with a single line: `<%= render(PostShowComponent, post: @post) %>`. It would be great to have an API like this:

```ruby
class PostsController < ApplicationController
def show
post = Post.find(params[:id])
render(PostShowComponent, post: post)
end
end
```
I could provide a PR with a failing feature test, if that helps.

Thank you , ushi

P.S. Found a workaround. Maybe its a good starting point:

```ruby
class ApplicationController
private

def render_component(component, args, **options)
options = options.reverse_merge(layout: true)
render(html: view_context.render(component, args) , options)
end
end
```

"

item.title: Unable to use elasticsearch fields starting with underscore in Grafana
item.description:
**What happened**: I tried to use the elasticsearch datasource in Grafana and it cannot detect my timestamp field as it starts with (two) underscores.

**What you expected to happen**: Grafana should allow fields starting with one or more underscores

**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible) **: Use `__timestamp` instead of `@timestamp` as the name of the date field in your mapping

**Anything else we need to know?**: A large number of my fields start with an underscore. The system is large and old with multiple writers and consumers, which makes it very difficult to change all these fields to not start with an underscore.

**Environment**:
- Grafana version: v6.3.5 (67bad72)
- Data source type & version: elasticsearch 6.4
- OS Grafana is installed on: Linux
- User OS & Browser: macOS Mojave, Chrome
- Grafana plugins: elasticsearch
- Others:
